topics.title: General information on Agency for Integrated Care

answer.body:
Advance Care Planning (ACP) is a series of conversations to let your family and doctors know how you want to be cared for in the event that you become unable to make decisions for yourself.


ACP allows you to make these decisions ahead of time, discuss the values that underlie these decisions, write down your wishes and communicate them with family members.


You may click here for more information on ACP.

Advance Care Planning (ACP) is for everybody, regardless of age or health condition. You are strongly encouraged to have these conversations with your loved ones as early as possible. Having your wishes documented in an ACP can also ensure that the medical team can be guided by your ACP in the future. ACP also gives your loved ones assurance and confidence to make medical decisions that are aligned with your wishes during a medical emergency.


You may click here for more information on ACP.

questionListItems.title: How do I start Advance Care Planning (ACP)?

answer.body:
Here are five steps to getting your Advance Care Planning (ACP) done:


1. Initiate the conversation with your loved ones. Share the importance of ACP and how it can benefit you and your family. You can use the tools available on www.livingmatters.sg to broach the ACP discussion.


2. If you are keen to explore ACP, you can make an appointment with your healthcare provider to explore the care options and the need for a formal ACP discussion with a trained ACP facilitator.

*An ACP facilitator is a trained healthcare professional who can guide your family and you through the discussion and document your preferences onto a form.

3. You are strongly encouraged to nominate a healthcare spokesperson - someone who can be your voice when you are not able to make decisions on your own.

4. Document your care preferences with the help of an ACP facilitator.

5. ACP is an ongoing process and wishes can be changed or updated at any time, especially when your medical condition or life circumstances change.


You may click here for more information on ACP.

questionListItems.title: Who can I speak to on Advance Care Planning (ACP)?

answer.body:
You can call 1800-650-6060 or click here if you have any enquiries on Advance Care Planning (ACP).


You can also speak to your healthcare provider to find out more about ACP.

questionListItems.title: Where can I get my Advance Care Plan done?

answer.body:
Advance Care Planning (ACP) may be done at most hospitals, selected polyclinics, and community care providers:

If you are a patient at a hospital or polyclinic, please ask your doctor for a referral.

If you are generally in good health, you may make an appointment at ACP nodes.

Some providers offer the option to do ACP over a video conferencing platform (please refer to the section on TeleACP Providers).

You may also apply for a Lasting Power of Attorney with selected service providers (indicated with blue background).

Advance Care Planning (ACP) facilitators are found in all the government restructured hospitals, polyclinics and community nodes. You can make an appointment to meet with an ACP facilitator to discuss your healthcare wishes and record them. Consultation fees may apply.

It is also recommended to bring along your loved ones and/or someone you can appoint to speak on your behalf when you can no longer do so, for the discussion.

Please click here for more information on where you can get your ACP done.

questionListItems.title: What is the Migrant Domestic Worker (FDW) Levy Concession?

answer.body:
The Migrant Domestic Worker (FDW) Levy Concession for Persons with Disabilities (PWD) lets families pay a monthly Migrant domestic worker levy of just $60, instead of $300. Each household gets concessions for up to two Migrant domestic workers for two loved ones in one household at the same time.


Please click here for more information on the scheme.

questionListItems.title: Who can apply for Migrant Domestic Worker (FDW) Levy Concession?

answer.body:
The FDW Levy Concession for PWD is applicable for care recipients between 16 to 66 years and with disabilities. Employers pay a lower monthly concessionary FDW levy of $60 (instead of $300) if they are eligible for this scheme.

Eligibility Criteria

1) Citizenship -

The care recipient must be a Singapore Citizen.

2) Medical assessment

A Singapore-registered doctor must certify that the care recipient needs permanent assistance in at least one Activity of Daily Living (ADL). A functional assessment is not required if your care recipient has an ElderShield/ IDAPE claims approval letter OR a memo/ document from any Singapore-registered doctor certifying that he/ she is bedridden.

3) Relationship with the care recipient

The FDW employer must be (a) the care recipient OR (b) a family member. In the case of (b), the employer and care recipient must live together at the same NRIC-registered address.


Please click here for more information on FDW levy Concession for PWD.

questionListItems.title: How do I apply for the Migrant Domestic Worker (FDW) Levy Concession?

answer.body:
The Migrant Domestic Worker (FDW) Levy Concession for Persons with Disabilities (PWD) lets families pay the Migrant Domestic Worker levy at a concessionary rate of $60 a month, instead of $300. Each household is eligible for up to two FDW levy concessions, caring for two loved ones at any one time.

How to Qualify

To be eligible for FDW Levy Concession for Persons with Disabilities, the care recipient must meet the following criteria:

Age

FDW employers caring for Person with Disabilities can apply.

For greater convenience, those who meet the age, citizenship and residential address eligibility criteria for the care of a young child (below 16) or aged person (67 years or above) need not apply for FDW levy concession. This is because MOM will grant you the concession based on the information you provided during your online application for an FDW.

Same Address

If you are hiring the Migrant domestic worker, you must be the care recipient, or living in the same address.

Nationality

Must be a Singapore Citizen

Requires Assistance with Activities of Daily Living

Always requires some assistance with at least one of the six Activities of Daily Living. These six activities are:

- Eating

- Bathing

- Dressing

- Transferring

- Toileting

- Walking or moving around

How to Apply

1. Obtain Approval

Obtain approval from the Ministry of Manpower (MOM)


You need approval from the Manpower Ministry to be able to hire an FDW. Click here to find out more about how to hire an FDW.


2. Assessment

Undergo disability assessment


Visit a General Practitioner (GP) or arrange with your care provider to obtain a Functional Assessment Report (FAR) *. The cost of an assessment may vary. Please contact your preferred assessor for more information.


Note: If you are also applying for severe disability schemes such as IDAPE/ElderFund, CareShield Life and MediSave Care, you do not need to obtain the FAR. Instead, contact an MOH-accredited severe disability assessor to undergo a disability assessment.


3. Application


Login to AIC’s eService portal (eFASS) with your Singpass.


We strongly encourage you to apply online as there is a shorter waiting time for application approval. If you are unable to submit your application using eFASS, please email us at apply@aic.sg or walk in to any of our AIC links to request for a hardcopy application form.


Please click here for more information on the Migrant Domestic Worker (FDW) Levy Concession for Persons with Disabilities (PWD).
